articles.headline: 11 Charged in Theft of 41 Million Card Numbers
articles.snippet: Authorities said the scheme was spearheaded by a Miami man who hacked into several retailers’ computer systems.
articles.abstract: Authorities said the scheme was spearheaded by a Miami man who hacked into several retailers’ computer systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have charged 11 people with stealing more than 41 million credit and debit card numbers, cracking what officials said on Tuesday appeared to be the largest hacking and identity theft ring ever exposed.

articles.headline: As Iraq Surplus Rises, Little Goes Into Rebuilding
articles.snippet: Rising oil prices will leave the Iraqi government with a budget surplus of as much as $79 billion, a report says.
articles.abstract: Rising oil prices will leave the Iraqi government with a budget surplus of as much as $79 billion, a report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soaring oil prices will leave the Iraqi government with a cumulative budget surplus of as much as $79 billion by year’s end, according to an American federal oversight agency. But Iraq has spent only a minute fraction of that on reconstruction costs, which are now largely borne by the United States.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Big Donors, Too, Have Seats at Obama Fund-Raising Table
articles.snippet: Barack Obama cites his small donations, but a third of his record-setting haul has come from gifts of $1,000 or more.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama cites his small donations, but a third of his record-setting haul has come from gifts of $1,000 or more.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an effort to cast himself as independent of the influence of money on politics, Senator Barack Obama often highlights the campaign contributions of $200 or less that have amounted to fully half of the $340 million he has collected so far.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Europe Tries to Handle Political Fallout of Pension Cuts
articles.snippet: Faced with an aging population, much of Europe is trying to address the pressing need for change in national pension systems, balancing rising costs with political pressure.
articles.abstract: Faced with an aging population, much of Europe is trying to address the pressing need for change in national pension systems, balancing rising costs with political pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Social Security is known as the “third rail” of American politics, and fiddling with retirement benefits can prove politically fatal in Europe too. Yet, in recent months and years some Europeans have tried to defuse the time bomb posed by millions of retirees receiving government benefits.

articles.headline: Star Pediatrician Fights Accusations of Sex Abuse
articles.snippet: Famous for treating learning problems, Dr. Melvin D. Levine has a 20-year history of allegations with little investigation.
articles.abstract: Famous for treating learning problems, Dr. Melvin D. Levine has a 20-year history of allegations with little investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For children struggling in school, Dr. Melvin D. Levine has been a great advocate. For decades, Dr. Levine, a pediatrician, has championed the idea that poorly performing students are not lazy or dumb, but instead need to be educated in a different way.

articles.headline: Lower Oil Prices Ignite Big Rally; Dow Is Up by 331
articles.snippet: Oil prices touched a three-month low, sending stocks soaring, while the Fed decided to keep its key rate steady.
articles.abstract: Oil prices touched a three-month low, sending stocks soaring, while the Fed decided to keep its key rate steady.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices touched a three-month low on Tuesday, the latest milestone in a steep reversal for commodity prices that sent stocks soaring and eased inflation concerns among investors and policy makers alike.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Louis Uchitelle

articles.headline: Chaos on the ‘Mountain That Invites Death’
articles.snippet: In all, 11 lives were lost in the worst episode on K2 since 13 climbers died over a two-week span in 1986.
articles.abstract: In all, 11 lives were lost in the worst episode on K2 since 13 climbers died over a two-week span in 1986.
articles.lead_paragraph: For two months, dozens of mountaineers had huddled at camps below the peak, acclimating to the thin air, practicing their ascent and waiting, waiting, for the moment.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Andrea Kannapell

articles.headline: Home Energy Prices Are Expected to Soar
articles.snippet: Even with the recent drop in oil prices, experts are predicting that heating bills this winter will far exceed those of last year.
articles.abstract: Even with the recent drop in oil prices, experts are predicting that heating bills this winter will far exceed those of last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a season of roller-coaster energy costs, the drop in oil and natural gas prices in recent days was greeted as good news. But they remain so high that experts are predicting that heating bills this winter will far exceed those of last year.

articles.headline: Sirius Chief Undaunted by Challenge
articles.snippet: The company, which completed its merger last week with XM Radio, has to persuade shareholders that it has a profitable future.
articles.abstract: The company, which completed its merger last week with XM Radio, has to persuade shareholders that it has a profitable future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mel Karmazin says he spent the past year of his life in constant fear that his dream deal  the merger of Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Radio  was about to unravel.

articles.headline: Freddie Mac’s Big Loss Dims Hopes of Turnaround
articles.snippet: Freddie Mac, the big mortgage finance company, reported a gaping quarterly loss and predicted that home prices would fall further than previously projected.
articles.abstract: Freddie Mac, the big mortgage finance company, reported a gaping quarterly loss and predicted that home prices would fall further than previously projected.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gloom over the nation’s housing market deepened on Wednesday as Freddie Mac, the big mortgage finance company, reported a gaping quarterly loss and predicted that home prices would fall further than previously projected.

articles.headline: Sprint Puts Positive Spin on Losses
articles.snippet: Sprint Nextel, the troubled No. 3 wireless carrier, lost nearly a million customers in the second quarter. But the company says it lost some of them on purpose.
articles.abstract: Sprint Nextel, the troubled No. 3 wireless carrier, lost nearly a million customers in the second quarter. But the company says it lost some of them on purpose.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprint Nextel, the troubled No. 3 wireless carrier, lost nearly a million customers in the second quarter. But the company says it lost some of them on purpose.
